postgresql-resource-postgresql_database.body:
resource "postgresql_database" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the database. Must be unique on the PostgreSQL server instance where it is configured.
    name = ""

    # owner - (Optional) The role name of the user who will own the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the default (namely, the user executing the command). To create a database owned by another role or to change the owner of an existing database, you must be a direct or indirect member of the specified role, or the username in the provider is a superuser.
    owner = ""

    # tablespace_name - (Optional) The name of the tablespace that will be associated with the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the template database's tablespace.  This tablespace will be the default tablespace used for objects created in this database.
    tablespace_name = ""

    # connection_limit - (Optional) How many concurrent connections can be established to this database. `-1` (the default) means no limit.
    connection_limit = ""

    # allow_connections - (Optional) If `false` then no one can connect to this database. The default is `true`, allowing connections (except as restricted by other mechanisms, such as `GRANT` or `REVOKE CONNECT`).
    allow_connections = ""

    # is_template - (Optional) If `true`, then this database can be cloned by any user with `CREATEDB` privileges; if `false` (the default), then only superusers or the owner of the database can clone it.
    is_template = ""

    # template - (Optional) The name of the template database from which to create the database, or `DEFAULT` to use the default template (`template0`).  NOTE: the default in Terraform is `template0`, not `template1`.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    template = ""

    # encoding - (Optional) Character set encoding to use in the database. Specify a string constant (e.g. `UTF8` or `SQL_ASCII`), or an integer encoding number.  If unset or set to an empty string the default encoding is set to `UTF8`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the same encoding as the template database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    encoding = ""

    # lc_collate - (Optional) Collation order (`LC_COLLATE`) to use in the database.  This affects the sort order applied to strings, e.g. in queries with `ORDER BY`, as well as the order used in indexes on text columns. If unset or set to an empty string the default collation is set to `C`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the same collation order as the specified `template` database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    lc_collate = ""

    # lc_ctype - (Optional) Character classification (`LC_CTYPE`) to use in the database. This affects the categorization of characters, e.g. lower, upper and digit. If unset or set to an empty string the default character classification is set to `C`.  If set to `DEFAULT` Terraform will use the character classification of the specified `template` database.  Changing this value will force the creation of a new resource as this value can only be changed when a database is created.
    lc_ctype = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_database.description:
The ``postgresql_database`` resource creates and manages [database
objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/managing-databases.html)
within a PostgreSQL server instance.

postgresql-resource-postgresql_extension.description:
The ``postgresql_extension`` resource creates and manages an extension on a PostgreSQL
server.

postgresql-resource-postgresql_role.body:
resource "postgresql_role" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the role. Must be unique on the PostgreSQL server instance where it is configured.
    name = ""

    # superuser - (Optional) Defines whether the role is a "superuser", and therefore can override all access restrictions within the database.  Default value is `false`.
    superuser = ""

    # create_database - (Optional) Defines a role's ability to execute `CREATE DATABASE`.  Default value is `false`.
    create_database = ""

    # create_role - (Optional) Defines a role's ability to execute `CREATE ROLE`. A role with this privilege can also alter and drop other roles.  Default value is `false`.
    create_role = ""

    # inherit - (Optional) Defines whether a role "inherits" the privileges of roles it is a member of.  Default value is `true`.
    inherit = ""

    # login - (Optional) Defines whether role is allowed to log in.  Roles without this attribute are useful for managing database privileges, but are not users in the usual sense of the word.  Default value is `false`.
    login = ""

    # replication - (Optional) Defines whether a role is allowed to initiate streaming replication or put the system in and out of backup mode.  Default value is `false`
    replication = ""

    # bypass_row_level_security - (Optional) Defines whether a role bypasses every row-level security (RLS) policy.  Default value is `false`.
    bypass_row_level_security = ""

    # connection_limit - (Optional) If this role can log in, this specifies how many concurrent connections the role can establish. `-1` (the default) means no limit.
    connection_limit = ""

    # encrypted_password - (Optional) Defines whether the password is stored encrypted in the system catalogs.  Default value is `true`.  NOTE: this value is always set (to the conservative and safe value), but may interfere with the behavior of [PostgreSQL's `password_encryption` setting](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/runtime-config-connection.html#GUC-PASSWORD-ENCRYPTION).
    encrypted_password = ""

    # password - (Optional) Sets the role's password. (A password is only of use for roles having the `login` attribute set to true, but you can nonetheless define one for roles without it.) Roles without a password explicitly set are left alone.  If the password is set to the magic value `NULL`, the password will be always be cleared.
    password = ""

    # valid_until - (Optional) Defines the date and time after which the role's password is no longer valid.  Established connections past this `valid_time` will have to be manually terminated.  This value corresponds to a PostgreSQL datetime. If omitted or the magic value `NULL` is used, `valid_until` will be set to `infinity`.  Default is `NULL`, therefore `infinity`.
    valid_until = ""

    # skip_drop_role - (Optional) When a PostgreSQL ROLE exists in multiple databases and the ROLE is dropped, the [cleanup of ownership of objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/role-removal.html) in each of the respective databases must occur before the ROLE can be dropped from the catalog.  Set this option to true when there are multiple databases in a PostgreSQL cluster using the same PostgreSQL ROLE for object ownership. This is the third and final step taken when removing a ROLE from a database.
    skip_drop_role = ""

    # skip_reassign_owned - (Optional) When a PostgreSQL ROLE exists in multiple databases and the ROLE is dropped, a [`REASSIGN OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-reassign-owned.html) in must be executed on each of the respective databases before the `DROP ROLE` can be executed to dropped the ROLE from the catalog.  This is the first and second steps taken when removing a ROLE from a database (the second step being an implicit [`DROP OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-drop-owned.html)).
    skip_reassign_owned = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_role.description:
The ``postgresql_role`` resource creates and manages a role on a PostgreSQL
server. When a ``postgresql_role`` resource is removed, the PostgreSQL ROLE will
automatically run a [`REASSIGN
OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-reassign-owned.html)
and [`DROP
OWNED`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-drop-owned.html) to
the `CURRENT_USER` (normally the connected user for the provider).  If the
specified PostgreSQL ROLE owns objects in multiple PostgreSQL databases in the
same PostgreSQL Cluster, one PostgreSQL provider per database must be created
and all but the final ``postgresql_role`` must specify a `skip_drop_role`. ~> **Note:** All arguments including role name and password will be stored in the raw state as plain-text.
[Read more about sensitive data in state](/docs/state/sensitive-data.html).

postgresql-resource-postgresql_schema.body:
resource "postgresql_schema" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the schema. Must be unique in the PostgreSQL
    name = ""

    # owner - (Optional) The ROLE who owns the schema.
    owner = ""

    # policy - (Optional) Can be specified multiple times for each policy.  Each
    policy = ""

    # create - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have CREATE privileges to the specified SCHEMA.
    create = ""

    # create_with_grant - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have CREATE privileges to the specified SCHEMA and the ability to GRANT the CREATE privilege to other ROLEs.
    create_with_grant = ""

    # role - (Optional) The ROLE who is receiving the policy.  If this value is empty or not specified it implies the policy is referring to the [`PUBLIC` role](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-grant.html).
    role = ""

    # usage - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have USAGE privileges to the specified SCHEMA.
    usage = ""

    # usage_with_grant - (Optional) Should the specified ROLE have USAGE privileges to the specified SCHEMA and the ability to GRANT the USAGE privilege to other ROLEs.
    usage_with_grant = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
postgresql-resource-postgresql_schema.description:
The ``postgresql_schema`` resource creates and manages [schema
objects](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/ddl-schemas.html) within
a PostgreSQL database.

rundeck-resource-job.body:
resource "rundeck_job" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The name of the plugin to execute.
    type = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the job to execute. The target job must be in the same project as the current job.
    name = ""

    # name - (Required) Unique name that will be shown in the UI when entering values and used as a variable name for template substitutions.
    name = ""

    # command - (Required) Nested block defining one step in the job workflow. A job must have one or more commands. The structure of this nested block is described below.
    command = ""

    # project_name - (Required) The name of the project that this job should belong to.
    project_name = ""

    # description - (Required) A longer description of the job, describing the job in the Rundeck UI.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the job, used to describe the job in the Rundeck UI.
    name = ""

    # group_name - (Optional) The name of a group within the project in which to place the job. Setting this creates collapsable subcategories within the Rundeck UI's project job index.
    group_name = ""

    # log_level - (Optional) The log level that Rundeck should use for this job. Defaults to "INFO".
    log_level = ""

    # allow_concurrent_executions - (Optional) Boolean defining whether two or more executions of this job can run concurrently. The default is `false`, meaning that jobs will only run sequentially.
    allow_concurrent_executions = ""

    # max_thread_count - (Optional) The maximum number of threads to use to execute this job, which controls on how many nodes the commands can be run simulateneously. Defaults to 1, meaning that the nodes will be visited sequentially.
    max_thread_count = ""

    # continue_on_error - (Optional) Boolean defining whether Rundeck will continue to run subsequent steps if any intermediate step fails. Defaults to `false`, meaning that execution will stop and the execution will be considered to have failed.
    continue_on_error = ""

    # rank_attribute - (Optional) The name of the attribute that will be used to decide in which order the nodes will be visited while executing the job across multiple nodes.
    rank_attribute = ""

    # rank_order - (Optional) Keyword deciding which direction the nodes are sorted in terms of the chosen `rank_attribute`. May be either "ascending" (the default) or "descending".
    rank_order = ""

    # preserve_options_order - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the configured options will be presented in their configuration order when shown in the Rundeck UI. The default is `false`, which means that the options will be displayed in alphabetical order by name.
    preserve_options_order = ""

    # command_ordering_strategy - (Optional) The name of the strategy used to describe how to traverse the matrix of nodes and commands. The default is "node-first", meaning that all commands will be executed on a single node before moving on to the next. May also be set to "step-first", meaning that a single step will be executed across all nodes before moving on to the next step.
    command_ordering_strategy = ""

    # node_filter_query - (Optional) A query string using [Rundeck's node filter language](http://rundeck.org/docs/manual/node-filters.html#node-filter-syntax) that defines which subset of the project's nodes will be used to execute this job.
    node_filter_query = ""

    # node_filter_exclude_precedence - (Optional) Boolean controlling a deprecated Rundeck feature that controls whether node exclusions take priority over inclusions.
    node_filter_exclude_precedence = ""

    # option - (Optional) Nested block defining an option a user may set when executing this job. A job may have any number of options. The structure of this nested block is described below.
    option = ""

    # option - (Optional) `option` blocks have the following structure:
    option = ""

    # default_value - (Optional) A default value for the option.
    default_value = ""

    # value_choices - (Optional) A list of strings giving a set of predefined values that the user may choose from when entering a value for the option.
    value_choices = ""

    # value_choices_url - (Optional) Can be used instead of `value_choices` to cause Rundeck to obtain a list of choices dynamically by fetching this URL.
    value_choices_url = ""

    # require_predefined_choice - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the user is allowed to enter values not included in the predefined set of choices (`false`, the default) or whether a predefined choice is required (`true`).
    require_predefined_choice = ""

    # validation_regex - (Optional) A regular expression that a provided value must match in order to be accepted.
    validation_regex = ""

    # description - (Optional) A longer description of the option to be shown in the UI.
    description = ""

    # required - (Optional) Boolean defining whether the user must provide a value for the option. Defaults to `false`.
    required = ""

    # allow_multiple_values - (Optional) Boolean defining whether the user may select multiple values from the set of predefined values. Defaults to `false`, meaning that the user may choose only one value.
    allow_multiple_values = ""

    # multi_value_delimiter - (Optional) Delimiter used to join together multiple values into a single string when `allow_multiple_values` is set and the user chooses multiple values.
    multi_value_delimiter = ""

    # obscure_input - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the value of this option should be obscured during entry and in execution logs. Defaults to `false`, but should be set to `true` when the requested value is a password, private key or any other secret value.
    obscure_input = ""

    # exposed_to_scripts - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the value of this option is available to scripts executed by job commands. Defaults to `false`.
    exposed_to_scripts = ""

    # command - (Optional) `command` blocks must have any one of the following combinations of arguments as contents:
    command = ""

    # description - (Optional) gives a description to the command block.
    description = ""

    # shell_command - (Optional) `shell_command` gives a single shell command to execute on the nodes.
    shell_command = ""

    # inline_script - (Optional) `inline_script` gives a whole shell script, inline in the configuration, to execute on the nodes.
    inline_script = ""

    # script_file - (Optional) `script_file` and `script_file_args` together describe a script that is already pre-installed on the nodes which is to be executed.
    script_file = ""

    # group_name - (Optional) The name of the group that the target job belongs to, if any.
    group_name = ""

    # run_for_each_node - (Optional) Boolean controlling whether the job is run only once (`false`, the default) or whether it is run once for each node (`true`).
    run_for_each_node = ""

    # args - (Optional) A string giving the arguments to pass to the target job, using [Rundeck's job arguments syntax](http://rundeck.org/docs/manual/jobs.html#job-reference-step).
    args = ""

    # config - (Optional) Map of arbitrary configuration parameters for the selected plugin.
    config = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - A unique identifier for the job.
    # "config": (Optional) Map of arbitrary configuration parameters for the selected plugin.
}
rundeck-resource-job.description:
The job resource allows Rundeck jobs to be managed by Terraform. In Rundeck a job is a particular
named set of steps that can be executed against one or more of the nodes configured for its
associated project. Each job belongs to a project. A project can be created with the `rundeck_project` resource.

rundeck-resource-private-key.body:
resource "rundeck_private_key" "$1" {
    # key_material - (Required) The private key material to store, serialized in any way that is accepted by OpenSSH.
    key_material = ""

    # path - (Required) The path within the key store where the key will be stored.
    path = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
rundeck-resource-private-key.description:
The private key resource allows SSH private keys to be stored into Rundeck's key store.
The key store is where Rundeck keeps credentials that are needed to access the nodes on which
it runs commands.

rundeck-resource-project.body:
resource "rundeck_project" "$1" {
    # config - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
    config = ""

    # type - (Required) The name of the resource model plugin to use.
    type = ""

    # resource_model_source - (Required) Nested block instructing Rundeck on how to determine the set of resources (nodes) for this project. The nested block structure is described below.
    resource_model_source = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the project, used both in the UI and to uniquely identify the project. Must therefore be unique across a single Rundeck installation.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the project, to be displayed in the Rundeck UI. Defaults to "Managed by Terraform".
    description = ""

    # default_node_file_copier_plugin - (Optional) The name of a plugin to use to copy files onto nodes within this project. Defaults to `jsch-scp`, which uses the "Secure Copy" protocol to send files over SSH.
    default_node_file_copier_plugin = ""

    # default_node_executor_plugin - (Optional) The name of a plugin to use to run commands on nodes within this project. Defaults to `jsch-ssh`, which uses the SSH protocol to access the nodes.
    default_node_executor_plugin = ""

    # ssh_authentication_type - (Optional) When the SSH-based file copier and executor plugins are used, the type of SSH authentication to use. Defaults to `privateKey`.
    ssh_authentication_type = ""

    # ssh_key_storage_path - (Optional) When the SSH-based file copier and executor plugins are used, the location within Rundeck's key store where the SSH private key can be found. Private keys can be uploaded to rundeck using the `rundeck_private_key` resource.
    ssh_key_storage_path = ""

    # ssh_key_file_path - (Optional) Like `ssh_key_storage_path` except that the key is read from the Rundeck server's local filesystem, rather than from the key store.
    ssh_key_file_path = ""

    # extra_config - (Optional) Behind the scenes a Rundeck project is really an arbitrary set of key/value pairs. This map argument allows setting any configuration properties that aren't explicitly supported by the other arguments described above, but due to limitations of Terraform the key names must be written with slashes in place of dots. Do not use this argument to set properties that the above arguments set, or undefined behavior will result.
    extra_config = ""

    # resource_model_source - (Optional) `resource_model_source` blocks have the following nested arguments:
    resource_model_source = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "name" - The unique name that identifies the project, as set in the arguments.
    # "config" - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
    # "ui_url" - The URL of the index page for this project in the Rundeck UI.
    # "config" - (Required) Map of arbitrary configuration properties for the selected resource model plugin.
}
rundeck-resource-project.description:
The project resource allows Rundeck projects to be managed by Terraform. In Rundeck a project
is the container object for a set of jobs and the configuration for which servers those jobs
can be run on.

rundeck-resource-public-key.body:
resource "rundeck_public_key" "$1" {
    # path - (Required) The path within the key store where the key will be stored. By convention this path name normally ends with ".pub" and otherwise has the same name as the associated private key.
    path = ""

    # key_material - (Optional) The public key string to store, serialized in any way that is accepted by OpenSSH. If this is not included, ``key_material`` becomes an attribute that can be used to read the already-existing key material in the Rundeck store.
    key_material = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "url" - The URL at which the key material can be retrieved from the key store by other clients.
    # "key_material" - If "key_material" is omitted in the configuration, it becomes an attribute that exposes the key material already stored at the given "path".
}
rundeck-resource-public-key.description:
The public key resource allows SSH public keys to be stored into Rundeck's key store.
The key store is where Rundeck keeps credentials that are needed to access the nodes on which
it runs commands. This resource also allows the retrieval of an existing public key from the store, so that it
may be used in the configuration of other resources such as ``aws_key_pair``.

softlayer-resource-ssh-key.body:
resource "ssh_key" "$1" {

    public_key = ""

    # name - (Required) A descriptive name used to identify an SSH key.
    name = ""

    # notes - (Optional) A small note about an SSH key to use at your discretion.
    notes = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the new SSH key
    # "fingerprint" - sequence of bytes to authenticate or lookup a longer SSH key.
}
softlayer-resource-ssh-key.description:
Provides SSK keys. This allows SSH keys to be created, updated and deleted.
For additional details please refer to [API documentation](http://sldn.softlayer.com/reference/datatypes/SoftLayer_Security_Ssh_Key).

softlayer-resource-virtual-guest.body:
resource "virtual_guest" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) `name` | *string*
    name = ""

    # domain - (Optional) `domain` | *string*
    domain = ""

    # cpu - (Optional) `cpu` | *int*
    cpu = ""

    # ram - (Optional) `ram` | *int*

softlayer-resource-virtual-guest.description:
Provides virtual guest resource. This allows virtual guests to be created, updated
and deleted. For additional details please refer to [API documentation](http://sldn.softlayer.com/reference/services/SoftLayer_Virtual_Guest).

statuscake-test.body:

    test_type = ""

    website_url = ""

    contact_id = ""

    # paused - (Optional) Whether or not the test is paused. Defaults to false.
    paused = ""

    # timeout - (Optional) The timeout of the test in seconds.
    timeout = ""

    # confirmations - (Optional) The number of confirmation servers to use in order to detect downtime. Defaults to 0.
    confirmations = ""

    # port - (Optional) The port to use when specifying a TCP test.
    port = ""

    # trigger_rate - (Optional) The number of minutes to wait before sending an alert. Default is `5`.
    trigger_rate = ""

    # "test_id" - A unique identifier for the test.
}
statuscake-test.description: The test resource allows StatusCake tests to be managed by Terraform.

vsphere-data-source-datacenter.description:
The `vsphere_datacenter` data source can be used to discover the ID of a
vSphere datacenter. This can then be used with resources or data sources that
require a datacenter, such as the [`vsphere_host`][data-source-vsphere-host]
data source.

vsphere-data-source-distributed-virtual-.body:
data "vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the distributed virtual switch. This can be a
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) The managed object reference ID of the
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-distributed-virtual-.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch` data source can be used to discover
the ID and uplink data of a of a vSphere distributed virtual switch (DVS). This
can then be used with resources or data sources that require a DVS, such as the
[`vsphere_distributed_port_group`][distributed-port-group] resource, for which
an example is shown below. ~> **NOTE:** This data source requires vCenter and is not available on direct
ESXi connections.

vsphere-data-source-host.body:
data "vsphere_host" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String) The name of the host. This can be a name or path.	Can be
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) (String, required) The managed object reference ID of a
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-host.description:
The `vsphere_host` data source can be used to discover the ID of a vSphere
host. This can then be used with resources or data sources that require a host
managed object reference ID.

vsphere-data-source-network.body:
data "vsphere_network" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the network. This can be a name or path.
    name = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) The managed object reference ID of the
    datacenter_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-network.description:
The `vsphere_network` data source can be used to discover the ID of a network
in vSphere. This can be any network that can be used as the backing for a
network interface for `vsphere_virtual_machine` or any other vSphere resource
that requires a network. This includes standard (host-based) port groups, DVS
port groups, or opaque networks such as those managed by NSX. ~> **NOTE:** This data source requires vCenter and is not available on direct
ESXi connections.

vsphere-data-source-tag-category.description:
The `vsphere_tag_category` data source can be used to reference tag categories
that are not managed by Terraform. Its attributes are exactly the same as the
[`vsphere_tag_category` resource][resource-tag-category], and, like importing,
the data source takes a name to search on. The `id` and other attributes are
then populated with the data found by the search. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-data-source-tag-data-source.body:
data "vsphere_tag" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required) The name of the tag.
    name = ""

    # category_id - (Optional) (String, required) The ID of the tag category the tag is
    category_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-data-source-tag-data-source.description:
The `vsphere_tag` data source can be used to reference tags that are not
managed by Terraform. Its attributes are exactly the same as the [`vsphere_tag`
resource][resource-tag], and, like importing, the data source takes a name and
category to search on. The `id` and other attributes are then populated with
the data found by the search. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-data-source-vmfs-disks.body:
data "vsphere_vmfs_disks" "$1" {
    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required) The managed object ID of the host to
    host_system_id = ""

    # rescan - (Optional) (Boolean, optional) Whether or not to rescan storage adapters
    rescan = ""

vsphere-data-source-vmfs-disks.description:
The `vsphere_vmfs_disks` data source can be used to discover the storage
devices available on an ESXi host. This data source can be combined with the
[`vsphere_vmfs_datastore`][data-source-vmfs-datastore] resource to create VMFS
datastores based off a set of discovered disks.

vsphere-resource-admin-license.body:
resource "vsphere_license" "$1" {
    # license_key - (Required) The license key to add.
    license_key = ""

    # labels - (Optional) A map of key/value pairs to be attached as labels (tags) to the license key.
    labels = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "edition_key" - The product edition of the license key.
    # "total" - Total number of units (example: CPUs) contained in the license.
    # "used" - The number of units (example: CPUs) assigned to this license.
    # "name" - The display name for the license.
}
vsphere-resource-admin-license.description: Provides a VMware vSphere license resource. This can be used to add and remove license keys.

    name = ""

    folder = ""

    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes

vsphere-resource-inventory-datacenter.description:
Provides a VMware vSphere datacenter resource. This can be used as the primary
container of inventory objects such as hosts and virtual machines.

vsphere-resource-inventory-folder.body:
resource "vsphere_folder" "$1" {
    # type - (Required) The type of folder to create. Allowed options are
    type = ""

    # path - (Required) The path of the folder to be created. This is relative to
    path = ""

    # vm - (Optional) `vm` (denoting a virtual machine folder), and a supplied folder of
    vm = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) `datacenter` for datacenter folders, `host` for host and cluster folders,
    datacenter = ""

    # vm - (Optional) `vm` for virtual machine folders, `datastore` for datastore folders, and
    vm = ""

    # network - (Optional) `network` for network folders. Forces a new resource if changed.
    network = ""

    # datacenter_id - (Optional) The ID of the datacenter the folder will be created in.
    datacenter_id = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The IDs of any tags to attach to this resource. See
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-inventory-folder.description:
The `vsphere_folder` resource can be used to manage vSphere inventory folders.
The resource supports creating folders of the 5 major types - datacenter
folders, host and cluster folders, virtual machine folders, datastore folders,
and network folders. Paths are always relative to the specific type of folder you are creating.
Subfolders are discovered by parsing the relative path specified in `name`, so
`foo/bar` will create a folder named `bar` in the parent folder `foo`, as long
as that folder exists.

vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-category.body:
resource "vsphere_tag_category" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required) The name of the category.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (String, optional) A description for the category.
    description = ""

    # cardinality - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The number of tags
    cardinality = ""

    # associable_types - (Optional) (List of strings, required) A list object types that
    associable_types = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-category.description:
The `vsphere_tag_category` resource can be used to create and manage tag
categories, which determine how tags are grouped together and applied to
specific objects. For more information about tags, click [here][ext-tags-general]. For more
information about tag categories specifically, click
[here][ext-tag-categories]. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-resource.body:
resource "vsphere_tag" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required) The display name of the tag. The name must be
    name = ""

    # category_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The unique identifier
    category_id = ""

    # description - (Optional) (String, optional) A description for the tag.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-inventory-tag-resource.description:
The `vsphere_tag` resource can be used to create and manage tags, which allow
you to attach metadata to objects in the vSphere inventory to make these
objects more sortable and searchable. For more information about tags, click [here][ext-tags-general]. ~> **NOTE:** Tagging support is unsupported on direct ESXi connections and
requires vCenter 6.0 or higher.

vsphere-resource-network-distributed-por.body:
resource "vsphere_distributed_port_group" "$1" {
    # distributed_virtual_switch_uuid - (Required) The ID of the DVS to add the
    distributed_virtual_switch_uuid = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the port group.
    name = ""

    # type - (Optional) The port group type. Can be one of `earlyBinding` (static
    type = ""

    # description - (Optional) An optional description for the port group.
    description = ""

    # number_of_ports - (Optional) The number of ports available on this port
    number_of_ports = ""

    # auto_expand - (Optional) Allows the port group to create additional ports
    auto_expand = ""

    # port_name_format - (Optional) An optional formatting policy for naming of
    port_name_format = ""

    # network_resource_pool_key - (Optional) The key of a network resource pool
    network_resource_pool_key = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-network-distributed-por.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_port_group` resource can be used to manage vSphere
distributed virtual port groups. These port groups are connected to distributed
virtual switches, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch`][distributed-virtual-switch] resource. Distributed port groups can be used as networks for virtual machines, allowing
VMs to use the networking supplied by a distributed virtual switch (DVS), with
a set of policies that apply to that individual newtork, if desired. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts]. For more information on vSphere DVS
portgroups, see [this page][ref-vsphere-dvportgroup]. ~> **NOTE:** This resource requires vCenter and is not available on direct ESXi
connections.

vsphere-resource-network-distributed-vir.body:
resource "vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch" "$1" {
    # datacenter_id - (Required) The ID of the datacenter where the distributed
    datacenter_id = ""

    # name - (Required) The name of the distributed virtual switch.
    name = ""

    # folder - (Optional) The folder to create the DVS in. Forces a new resource
    folder = ""

    # description - (Optional) A detailed description for the DVS.
    description = ""

    # contact_name - (Optional) The name of the person who is responsible for the
    contact_name = ""

    # contact_detail - (Optional) The detailed contact information for the person
    contact_detail = ""

    # lacp_api_version - (Optional) The Link Aggregation Control Protocol group
    lacp_api_version = ""

    # link_discovery_operation - (Optional) Whether to `advertise` or `listen`
    link_discovery_operation = ""

    # link_discovery_protocol - (Optional) The discovery protocol type. Valid
    link_discovery_protocol = ""

    # max_mtu - (Optional) The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the virtual
    max_mtu = ""

    # multicast_filtering_mode - (Optional) The multicast filtering mode to use
    multicast_filtering_mode = ""

    # version - (Optional) - The version of the DVS to create. The default is to
    version = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The IDs of any tags to attach to this resource. See
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-network-distributed-vir.description:
The `vsphere_distributed_virtual_switch` resource can be used to manage VMware
Distributed Virtual Switches. An essential component of a distributed, scalable VMware datacenter, the
vSphere Distributed Virtual Switch (DVS) provides centralized management and
monitoring of the networking configuration of all the hosts that are associated
with the switch. In addition to adding port groups (see the
[`vsphere_distributed_port_group`][distributed-port-group] resource) that can
be used as networks for virtual machines, a DVS can be configured to perform
advanced high availability, traffic shaping, network monitoring, and more. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts]. For more information on vSphere DVS, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-dvs]. ~> **NOTE:** This resource requires vCenter and is not available on direct ESXi
connections.

vsphere-resource-networking-host-port-gr.body:
resource "vsphere_host_port_group" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of the port group.
    name = ""

    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The managed object
    host_system_id = ""

    # virtual_switch_name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of
    virtual_switch_name = ""

    # vlan_id - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The VLAN ID/trunk mode for this port group.
    vlan_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-networking-host-port-gr.description:
The `vsphere_host_port_group` resource can be used to manage vSphere standard
port groups on an ESXi host. These port groups are connected to standard
virtual switches, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_host_virtual_switch`][host-virtual-switch] resource. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts].

vsphere-resource-networking-host-virtual.body:
resource "vsphere_host_virtual_switch" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The name of the virtual switch.
    name = ""

    # host_system_id - (Optional) (String, required, forces new resource) The managed object
    host_system_id = ""

    # mtu - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the virtual
    mtu = ""

    # number_of_ports - (Optional) (Integer, optional) The number of ports to create with
    number_of_ports = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
vsphere-resource-networking-host-virtual.description:
The `vsphere_host_virtual_switch` resource can be used to manage vSphere
standard switches on an ESXi host. These switches can be used as a backing for
standard port groups, which can be managed by the
[`vsphere_host_port_group`][host-port-group] resource. For an overview on vSphere networking concepts, see [this
page][ref-vsphere-net-concepts].

vsphere-resource-storage-file.body:
resource "vsphere_file" "$1" {
    # datastore - (Required) The name of the Datastore in which to upload the file to.
    datastore = ""

    # destination_file - (Required) The path to where the file should be uploaded or copied to on vSphere.
    destination_file = ""

    # source_file - (Required) The path to the file being uploaded from the Terraform host to vSphere or copied within vSphere.
    source_file = ""

    # source_datacenter - (Optional) The name of a Datacenter in which the file will be copied from.
    source_datacenter = ""

    # datacenter - (Optional) The name of a Datacenter in which the file will be uploaded to.
    datacenter = ""

    # source_datastore - (Optional) The name of the Datastore in which file will be copied from.
    source_datastore = ""

    # create_directories - (Optional) Create directories in `destination_file` path parameter if any missing for copy operation.  *Note: Directories are not deleted on destroy operation.
    create_directories = ""

    # Exported Attributes

vsphere-resource-storage-file.description: Provides a VMware vSphere virtual machine file resource. This can be used to upload files (e.g. vmdk disks) from the Terraform host machine to a remote vSphere.  The file resource can also be used to copy files within vSphere.  Files can be copied between Datacenters and/or Datastores. Updates to file resources will handle moving a file to a new destination (datacenter and/or datastore and/or destination_file).  If any source parameter (e.g. `source_datastore`, `source_datacenter` or `source_file`) are changed, this results in a new resource (new file uploaded or copied and old one being deleted).

vsphere-resource-storage-nas-datastore.description:
The `vsphere_nas_datastore` resource can be used to create and manage NAS
datastores on an ESXi host or a set of hosts. The resource supports mounting
NFS v3 and v4.1 shares to be used as datastores. ~> **NOTE:** Unlike [`vsphere_vmfs_datastore`][resource-vmfs-datastore], a NAS
datastore is only mounted on the hosts you choose to mount it on. To mount on
multiple hosts, you must specify each host that you want to add in the
`host_system_ids` argument.

vsphere-resource-storage-vmfs-datastore.description:
The `vsphere_vmfs_datastore` resource can be used to create and manage VMFS
datastores on an ESXi host or a set of hosts. The resource supports using any
SCSI device that can generally be used in a datastore, such as local disks, or
disks presented to a host or multiple hosts over Fibre Channel or iSCSI.
Devices can be specified manually, or discovered using the
[`vsphere_vmfs_disks`][data-source-vmfs-disks] data source.

vsphere-resource-vm-virtual-machine-snap.description:
The `vsphere_virtual_machine_snapshot` resource can be used to manage snapshots
for a virtual machine. For more information on managing snapshots and how they work in VMware, see
[here][ext-vm-snapshot-management]. ~> **NOTE:** A snapshot in VMware differs from traditional disk snapshots in
that the actual running state of the virtual machine can be taken with the
snapshot as well, all non-independent disks are included in the snapshot
(including any disks that have been attached externally but are not
independent), and VM and disk activity post-snapshot is not included in the
original state. Use this resource with care! VMware nor HashiCorp recommends
retaining snapshots for a extended period of time and does NOT recommend using
them as as backup feature. For more information on the limitation of virtual
machine snapshots, see [here][ext-vm-snap-limitations].
